JUDGES: George Nicolaou;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä;Vincent A. De Gaetano
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE , died in DATE and lived in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by PERSON a lawyer practising in PERSON . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr J. PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
From DATE , the applicant was the president of the board of directors of a company , ORG . z o.o . ( ORG ) . As a result of financial problems , the company went into liquidation on DATE .
In DATE the appointed trustee informed ORG that the company had been making losses since DATE and the bankruptcy petition should have been lodged much earlier .
On DATE ORG of ORG instituted of its own motion proceedings against the applicant for failure to comply with the insolvency procedure .
The court scheduled a hearing for DATE . However , the applicant did not participate in this hearing , as on DATE and on DATE he appeared before ORG , where his presence was obligatory .

On DATE the ORG gave a decision and barred the applicant from conducting any economic activity on his own account , from performing the functions of a representative or proxy of an entrepreneur , from being a member of the supervisory board and audit commission in a joint stock company , limited liability company or a cooperative for DATE . In addition it ordered that the applicant be listed in the insolvency register . The court considered that the applicant , acting as the president of the board of ORG . z o.o . , had failed to comply with the insolvency procedure and had filed the petition for insolvency too late .
The applicant appealed against this decision .
At a hearing held on DATE ORG of ORG dismissed his appeal . The court held , in particular , that :

“ The evidence gathered by ORG of its own motion does not demonstrate that the applicant was not guilty of delaying the insolvency petition . In addition he was completely passive in the proceedings before ORG . ”
After pronouncement of the decision , the court informed the applicant ’s representative that a cassation appeal was not available .

On DATE the applicant ’s representative filed a cassation appeal against the second - instance decision . He stressed that he had been aware of ORG case - law about unavailability of a cassation appeal in the proceedings under section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW . However , in his opinion , after GPE ’s accession to the ORG , ORG should re - examine the issue .

On DATE ORG rejected the cassation appeal as inadmissible in law . The court held that the proceedings had been instituted before DATE and therefore LAW applied . As it appeared from ORG case - law , it was not possible to file a cassation appeal against a decision of a second - instance court given pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW .

The applicant appealed against this decision , arguing that the availability of a cassation appeal in the proceedings under LAW was not clear and emerged from the legal doctrine rather than from a clear provision of law . In addition , a new law on insolvency enacted in DATE expressly provided for the possibility of filing a cassation appeal in a similar situation .

On DATE ORG dismissed this appeal , upholding the decision of DATE . The court stressed that the new insolvency law of CARDINAL DATE clearly provided that the proceedings instituted before DATE should be examined under the DATE insolvency law . In addition , it held that despite the applicant ’s statements the current case - law was very clear about the unavailability of the cassation appeal . This decision was served on the applicant ’s representative on DATE .
The Ordinance of the President of GPE of DATE – LAW , as applicable at the material time – set out the rules governing insolvency proceedings . In so far as relevant it provided :
Section CARDINAL
“ § CARDINAL . An entrepreneur who has ceased to pay debts shall present , within DATE thereof , a bankruptcy petition to the court .

§ CARDINAL . A representative of the entrepreneur referred to under LAW paragraph CARDINAL shall present a bankruptcy petition within DATE from DATE when the assets have ceased to suffice to satisfy the debts unless the time - limit referred to under paragraph CARDINAL has already begun to run .
Section CARDINAL

“ § CARDINAL . Any person who has not fulfilled the duty referred to under LAW paragraph CARDINAL or CARDINAL shall be deprived , for DATE , of the right to conduct economic activity on his own account and to perform the functions of a representative or proxy of an entrepreneur , member of the supervisory board and audit commission in a joint stock company , limited liability company or co - operative , unless the said person is not guilty thereof .
§ CARDINAL . Issues referred to under paragraph l shall be subject to adjudication by the court conducting the proceedings for declaration of bankruptcy .
§ CARDINAL . The court shall institute the proceedings of its own motion .
§ CARDINAL . The court shall issue the decision on having conducted a trial .
§ CARDINAL . The court ’s decision on the ban referred to under paragraph CARDINAL shall be subject to appeal .

§ CARDINAL . Issues referred to under paragraph l , as regards their scope not regulated under paragraphs CARDINAL to CARDINAL shall be subject to the provisions of LAW on non - litigious proceedings . ”

On DATE the ORG delivered a judgment and declared that section CARDINAL was in compliance with the LAW . While the court did not rule on what kind of liability it provided , it noted that section CARDINAL² did not provide for a criminal sanction .

On DATE , the new Law on Insolvency and Restructuring was enacted . The relevant provision is now regulated by section CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of that law expressly provides for the possibility of filing a cassation appeal against a decision of a second - instance court . However , according to the introductory provisions , the new law applied only to proceedings instituted after DATE .
